PIL@NENPs composite as a synergetic heterogeneous catalyst to enhance the efficiency of CO2 cycloaddition with epoxides Yi Liu Conceptualization Investigation Methodology Formal analysis Data curation Writing – original draft Writing – review & editing Visualization a Lan Shi Investigation Writing – review & editing Visualization a Manoj Pudukudy Writing – review & editing Supervision Visualization b Shuangjiang Li Investigation Data curation a Tingyan Ye Writing – review & editing a Shaoyun Shan Resources Writing – review & editing Supervision Funding acquisition Project administration a ⁎ Tianding Hu Methodology Data curation a Waseem Tariq Writing – review & editing a Yunfei Zhi Writing – review & editing Supervision Resources Funding acquisition a ⁎ a Faculty of Chemical Engineering, Kunming University of Science and Technology, Kunming, Yunnan 650500, China Faculty of Chemical Engineering Kunming University of Science and Technology Kunming Yunnan 650500 China aFaculty of Chemical Engineering, Kunming University of Science and Technology, Kunming, Yunnan 650500, China b Department of Chemistry, Saveetha School of Engineering, Saveetha Institute of Medical and Technical Sciences, Chennai, Tamilnadu 602105, India Department of Chemistry Saveetha School of Engineering Saveetha Institute of Medical and Technical Sciences Chennai Tamilnadu 602105 India bDepartment of Chemistry, Saveetha School of Engineering, Saveetha Institute of Medical and Technical Sciences, Chennai, Tamilnadu 602105, India ⁎ Corresponding authors. The conversion CO2 into highly value-added chemicals requires the development of efficient heterogenous catalysts in the cycloaddition reaction. Herein, the covalent integration strategy of amino-functionalized poly(ionic liquid)s (PIL-NH2HBr) with nitrogen-enriched nano-porous polytriazines (NENPs) was used to synthesize a novel hybrid catalyst, labelled as PIL@NENPs. Several characterization techniques were used to confirm the effective synthesis of PIL-NH2HBr, NENPs and PIL@NENPs composites. Through the PIL-NH2HBr surface integration, the CO2 adsorption capacity of NENPs was greatly improved in the PIL@NENPs composites. The catalytic activity studies shown that the PIL@NENPs exhibited better catalytic activity than PIL-NH2HBr and NENPs in CO2 cycloaddition reaction due to their synergetic effects. Moreover, the PIL@NENPs composite was found to be very easy to separate, had shown good stability and recyclability, and very effective for a variety of epoxides in the CO2 cycloaddition reaction. The Density Functional Theory (DFT) calculations further revealed that the epoxides were activated by hydrogen bond donor (HBD) groups and Br anions whereas the CO2 was activated by N sites. Finally, combining the DFT calculations and activities of different catalysts, a possible reaction mechanism for CO2 cycloaddition catalyzed by PIL@NENPs was proposed. Graphical abstract The composite heterogeneous catalyst realizes the integration of multiple active sites and effectively catalyzes CO2 cycloaddition. Image, graphical abstract Keywords Melamine-based polymers Poly(ionic liquid)s Multifunction catalyst Covalent integration CO2 cycloaddition Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction Carbon dioxide (CO2) is the primary component of greenhouse gas, but it is also an easily available and valuable carbon resource [1–3]. The effective use of CO2 can alleviate the greenhouse effect and can also create enhanced economic values and social benefits [4–6]. The reported conversion of CO2 into various valuable chemicals such as oxazolidinones [7], cyclic carbonates [8], carbamates [9], and dimethyl carbonates [10] have attracted extensive attention in the modern research. In particular, CO2 cycloaddition with epoxides to synthesize cyclic carbonates has the benefits of 100 % atom economy, and less formation of by-products [11]. Moreover, the obtained cyclic carbonates are useful and widely applied in the organic synthesis [12], lithium battery electrolytes [13], polar solvents [14], and monomers for synthesizing polyesters [15]. However, the high thermodynamic stability of CO2 limits its chemical conversion, hence efficient catalysts need to be urgently developed [16,17]. In recent years, a variety of catalysts have been synthesized for CO2 cycloaddition with epoxides [18–20]. Although homogeneous catalysts have high activity, the difficulty of recovery limits their development. And the after-treatment of homogeneous catalysts requires organic solvents, which will further increase the production costs and cause environmental pollution [21]. The heterogeneous catalysts have the advantages of simple recovery, recyclability and easy surface modification [22]. However, the activity of heterogeneous catalysts is relatively low, and co-catalysts are often required to show satisfactory catalytic performance, which will undoubtedly increase the production and purification costs [23–25]. The development of green and efficient heterogeneous catalytic systems without the usage of co-catalysts is therefore still considered to be a major challenge. The design of catalysts based on the CO2 cycloaddition mechanism is critical to solve the aforementioned problems. The studies had shown that the epoxides can be activated by metals or hydrogen bond donor (HBD) groups such as -COOH, -NH2/-NH-, and -OH groups [26–28]. The lone pair electrons in N atoms and halide anions acts as nucleophiles which can attack the epoxides to promote their ring opening process [29–31]. Furthermore, the CO2 can be adsorbed and activated effectively by N atoms present in the catalyst structure [32]. However, many of the reported catalysts have only single active site, which cannot meet the higher activity requirements under co-catalyst-free conditions. Therefore, it is urged to develop a strategy for integrating multifunctional and synergistic groups into a catalytic system to enhance their catalytic activity. Poly(ionic liquid)s (PILs) are reported to have anions and cations with different functionalities, and have the advantages of facile functional group design in its structure, easy recovery, and adjustable pore structure [33]. In particular, some specific anions such as halides in PILs can act as nucleophiles. However, PILs are still limited for catalyzing the CO2 cycloaddition with epoxides, as the epoxides cannot be well activated by single active site [34,35]. In a previous research, nitrogen-enriched nano-porous polytriazines (NENPs) were successfully prepared though the simple polycondensation of melamine and cyanuric chloride [36,37]. The abundant triazine structure of NENPs have sufficient N sites and porosity and that has been applied in the field of CO2 adsorption [38]. It is worth to note that the NENPs contains abundant HBD groups (-NH-) which are not effectively utilized yet for the catalytic applications. In addition, the synergistic catalytic effect between metal organic framework (MOFs) materials and ILs has given great inspiration [39]. Therefore, in order to integrate the multiple active sites and construct a nitrogen-enriched environment that can favour for the CO2 cycloaddition, the PIL@NENPs composite was prepared. The amino-functionalized PILs such as PIL-NH2HBr was firstly synthesized by the polymerization reaction. Subsequently, the NENPs was in-situ synthesized on PIL-NH2HBr by the condensation of cyanuric chloride and melamine (Scheme 1 ). The chemical composition and structural and textural properties of the prepared materials such as PIL-NH2HBr, NENPs, and PIL@NENPs were determined by using different characterization techniques. The results confirmed the successful synthesis of PIL@NENPs. The excellent CO2 adsorption capacity of NENPs was further integrated onto PIL@NENPs, which provides a favorable environment for the subsequent CO2 catalytic conversion. The catalytic experiments had shown that PIL@NENPs composite exhibited better catalytic activity for the cycloaddition reaction than PIL-NH2HBr and NENPs owing to the surface integration strategy and the synergy of multiple active sites. Through Density Functional Theory (DFT) simulations, the interactions of epoxides and CO2 with various catalytic active sites in PIL@NENPs were further investigated in detail. Finally, based on the DFT calculations and literature, a possible mechanism for the synergistic catalysis of CO2 cycloaddition by multiple active sites in PIL@NENPs was proposed. This paper reports a composite catalyst integrated with multiple active sites, which is expected to provide a reference for the synthesis of catalysts with multiple active sites by integration strategies for the cycloaddition of CO2 with epoxides. 2 Experimental 2.1 Materials The chemicals, Divinylbenzene (DVB, 80 %), azobisisobutyronitrile (AIBN, 98 %), 2-bromoethylamine hydrobromide (98 %), 1-vinylimidazole (99 %), cyanuric chloride (99 %), melamine (MA, 99 %), dimethyl sulfoxide (DMSO, >99 %), potassium hydroxide (95 %), chloroform-d (CDCl3, D.99.8 %, 0.03 % TMS), epichlorohydrin (ECH, AR), styrene oxide (98 %), 1,2-epoxyhexane (96 %), propylene oxide (99 %) and 1,2-butylene oxide (>99 %) were purchased from Aladdin Chemicals, China and used directly without further purification. Methanol (AR), dichloroethane (AR) and ethanol (AR) were obtained from Xilong Scientific Co., Ltd. The gases such as N2 (99.99 %) and CO2 (99.99 %) were purchased from Kunming Guangruida Co., Ltd. 2.2 Synthesis of nitrogen-enriched nano-porous polytriazines (NENPs) Typically, 1.26 g melamine (10 mmol) and 1.84 g cyanuric chloride (10 mmol) were firstly added to a 250 mL flask with 50 mL DMSO, and then 1.68 g KOH (30 mmol) was added into it. The mixture was further stirred and refluxed at 120℃ for 12 h. The mixture was then subjected to centrifugation and the obtained crude product was washed with DMSO and methanol. The final product was dried under vacuum at 60℃ overnight to obtain a white fluffy powder, which is labelled as nitrogen-enriched nano-porous polytriazines (NENPs). 2.3 Synthesis of amino-functionalized poly(ionic liquid)s (PIL-NH2HBr) Before synthesizing the amino functionalized poly(ionic liquid)s (PIL-NH2HBr), 1-aminoethyl-3-vinylimidazolium-bromide·hydrobromide, [AVIM]Br·HBr was synthesized [10]. Typically, 2.05 g 2-bromoethylamine hydrobromide (10.0 mmol) and 0.94 g 1-vinylimidazole (10.0 mmol) were placed in an RB flask with 20 mL acetonitrile. Then, the mixture was stirred and refluxed at 80 ℃ for 24 h under N2 atmosphere. The obtained solid crude product was recovered by centrifugation, washed with ethanol to remove unreacted impurities, and dried under vacuum at 60°C. Next PIL-NH2HBr was prepared by copolymerizing the prepared [AVIM]Br·HBr with DVB. In a typical synthesis, 1.30 g DVB (10 mmol), 2.99 g [AVIM]Br·HBr (10 mmol) and 0.16 g initiator AIBN (1 mmol) were placed in a RB flask with 50 mL ethanol/water mixture (V/V=4:1). The mixture was then stirred and refluxed at 80℃ for 24 h under N2 atmosphere. The crude product was finally recovered by centrifugation, washed several times with ethanol, and dried under vacuum at 60℃ to obtain a white powder. The sample was labelled as PIL-NH2HBr. 2.4 Synthesis of PIL@NENPs composite In a typical procedure, 2 g of synthesized PIL-NH2HBr, 0.74 g cyanuric chloride (4 mmol, and 2.24 g KOH (40 mmol) were added into a flask with 50 mL DMSO. The mixture was first heated and stirred at 120℃ for 2 h, and then 30 mL DMSO solution containing 1.11 g cyanuric chloride (6 mmol) and 1.01 g melamine (8 mmol) were added to the mixture at 120℃. The heating process was further continued for 10 h and finally the formed solid product was separated by filtration. Finally, the product was vacuum-dried at 60℃ to obtain the final sample, i.e. nitrogen-enriched nano-porous polytriazines integrated poly(ionic liquid)s composites and labelled as PIL@NENPs. 2.5 Characterization techniques The prepared samples were subjected to various characterization techniques for their structural, textural and morphological features. The Fourier transform infrared (FT-IR) spectra of the samples were recorded on a Bruker Vertex 70 V Spectrometer using anhydrous KBr pellets method. The Liquid 1H NMR spectra of the samples were recorded on a Bruker Avance III HD 600 MHz spectrometer. The Solid-state 13C spectra of the prepared samples were recorded on a Bruker Advance III 400 MHz spectrometer. The X-ray photoelectron spectroscopic (XPS) analysis was performed on a Thermo-Fisher-ESCALAB 250Xi spectrometer. The CO2 adsorption isotherms and N2 adsorption-desorption isotherms were studied by using a Micromeritics ASAP 2460 adsorption analyzer. The morphological characteristics and the element distribution in the sample were investigated by using a Nova-Nano 450 scanning electron microscope (SEM) operated at an accelerating voltage of 10 kV. 2.6 Catalytic activity for the cycloaddition reaction The catalytic activity of the prepared samples for the cycloaddition of CO2 with epoxides were carried out in an autoclave as reported in our previous works [40,41]. Typically, 50 mg catalyst and 25 mmol epoxide were loaded into the autoclave, and then flushed with CO2 three times to remove other impurity gases. Thereafter, the reaction temperature, time and the initial CO2 pressure were adjusted. In the catalyst activity investigation experiment, the solid phase catalyst was separated from the reaction mixture by simple filtration, and the liquid phase product was characterized by using 1H NMR analysis with CDCl3 as solvent and TMS as internal standard. The selectivity and yield of products were calculated from the peak integration method of 1H NMR spectra as previously reported [42–44], and the calculation formula was in the support information Section 1. In the cyclic experiment, after the completion of each catalytic reaction, the PIL@NENPs sample was first separated by filtration, then washed with methanol, and finally vacuum dried at 60°C for subsequent catalytic reaction cycles. 2.7 Computational studies A Gaussian 09 package was used for density functional theory (DFT) calculations. Firstly, the geometry of PIL@NENPs composite was optimized, and then the interactions between ECH and CO2 with PIL@NENPs were calculated. The bond angles and bond lengths of the catalysts and reactants are expressed in degrees (◦) and angstroms (Å) respectively. A set of previous reported articles further provided considerable evidence for the accuracy of the calculations [16,45]. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Characterization of the prepared samples The structural properties of PIL-NH2HBr, NENPs, and PIL@NENPs were determined by FT-IR (Fig. 1 (a)) and solid-state 13C NMR (Fig. 1(b)) spectroscopic methods. In the FT-IR spectrum of PIL-NH2HBr sample, the obvious characteristic bands at 2920 cm−1, 1600 cm−1, 1445 cm−1 and 709 cm−1 were corresponded to the vibrational frequency of C-H and C=C bonds present in the benzene ring [46,47]. The characteristic bands of PIL-NH2HBr at 1160 cm−1 and 1632 cm−1 were corresponded to the C-N stretching vibration of the amino-alkyl chain and the skeleton vibration of the imidazole ring respectively, which indicated that the [AVIM]Br·HBr monomer was successfully polymerized with DVB [10,48]. In the FT-IR spectrum of NENPs, the obvious broad band seen in the region of 3090-3670 cm−1 was attributed to the stretching vibration of -NH- bond, indicating successful polymerization of cyanuric chloride with melamine [38]. The characteristic bands at 1550 cm−1 and 1340 cm−1 were attributed to the triazine ring, indicating that the skeleton of the triazine ring is preserved in the NENPs [49]. In the FT-IR spectrum of PIL@NENPs, the characteristic transmission bands of triazine ring (1550 cm−1 and 1340 cm−1) and benzene ring (709 and 2920 cm−1) were appeared simultaneously, and the stretching vibration of -NH- group (3090-3670 cm−1) was also not weakened. In addition, a new characteristic transmission band was appeared at 1148 cm−1, which could be related to the C-N bond formed by the covalent bonding between PIL-NH2HBr and NENPs [50]. The above results indicated that the PIL-NH2HBr was successfully complexed with NENPs through covalent interaction. The detailed structural composition of the prepared NENPs, PIL-NH2HBr and PIL@NENPs were further characterized by solid-state 13C NMR spectroscopy. Obviously, the NENPs sample exhibited only one strong peak at the δ value of 166 ppm, which is related to the carbon signal on triazine ring (Ca) [51]. In second solid-state 13C NMR spectra, two characteristic signals of PIL-NH2HBr were observed at around 128 ppm and 145 ppm. It could be ascribed to the presence of carbon signals on the benzene ring (Ck, Cj) [52]. The three characteristic peaks at the δ values of 112 ppm, 115 ppm, and 138 ppm were attributed to the carbon signals of the imidazole ring (Ce, Cf, Cd) [46]. The overlapped broad signal in the region of 25-60 ppm was attributed to the carbon signal on the alkyl chain generated after the alkenyl polymerization reaction (Ci, Cg, Ch) and the carbon signal of the alkyl chain is inherent in the [AVIM]Br·HBr (Cb, Cc) [10,47]. The PIL@NENPs simultaneously displayed all the characteristic carbon signals of PIL-NH2HBr and NENPs in the solid-state 13C NMR spectra, which further confirmed the successful integration of PIL-NH2HBr with NENPs for the preparation of PIL@NENPs hybrid materials. The pore parameters of PIL-NH2HBr, NENPs, and PIL@NENPs were measured by N2 adsorption/desorption isotherms. Clearly, all of the prepared samples had the same textural trend, showing a type-IV isotherm with H3 hysteresis loop (Fig. 2 (a–c)). In the low-pressure region (P/P0<0.1), the three samples have a certain amount of nitrogen sorption, indicating that there is a microporous structure in it. In high-pressure region, the N2 adsorption of the three samples increased sharply, indicating the presence of macropores. In addition, in the middle region, the adsorption curves of the samples showed a slowly rising trend, and the adsorption-desorption curves all appear in hysteresis loops, which means that there is a mesoporous structure in the samples. The results had shown that the three polymers contain three types of pores such as micropores, mesoporous, and macropores in it and the pore size distribution curves shown in the inset figure further verifies this conclusion. The presence of multi-porous structure in the sample is expected to enhance their catalytic activity for reaction. Notably, during the CO2 cycloaddition, the multi-level porous structure is favorable for the diffusion of CO2 and substrates such as epoxides and products, which is advantageous for improving the catalytic efficiency [53]. Table 1 show the detailed pore parameters of PIL-NH2HBr, NENPs and PIL@NENPs. The BET surface area of PIL-NH2HBr, NENPs, and PIL@NENPs was measured to be 101.5 m2/g, 117.8 m2/g, and 28.2 m2/g, respectively. The average pore diameter of PIL-NH2HBr, NENPs, and PIL@NENPs was estimated to be 4 nm, 3 nm, and 3.8 nm, and the total pore volume was measured to 0.658, 0.455 and 0.229 cm3/g, respectively. Compared to PIL-NH2HBr and NENPs, the BET surface area and pore parameters of PIL@NENPs was found to be lowered, which might be caused by the linking and aggregation effect of the post-synthesized NENPs in the hybrid material. The CO2 uptake capacity of the prepared samples such as PIL-NH2HBr, NENPs, and PIL@NENPs at 273 K were further investigated and the results are shown in Fig. 2(d). The CO2 adsorption capacities of PIL-NH2HBr, NENPs, and PIL@NENPs were increased continuously with increasing the relative pressure. Even though the PIL-NH2HBr and NENPs samples had similar BET surface area, the CO2 uptake capacity of NENPs was found to be significantly higher than that of PIL-NH2HBr, which could be attributed to the fact that the NENPs have more active nitrogen sites in their structure with strong interaction with CO2. Moreover, the CO2 uptake of PIL@NENPs was found to be significantly higher than that of PIL-NH2HBr due to its combination with NENPs, regardless of the low BET surface area of PIL@NENPs. Table 1 showed the CO2 uptake of PIL-NH2HBr, NENPs, and PIL@NENPs at 273 K and it was measured to be 17.3 cm3/g, 45.7 cm3/g, and 32.0 cm3/g, respectively. The results further demonstrated the success of the composite strategy with integrated multiple active sites in the hybrid catalyst and is expected to provide a favorable environment for the CO2 cycloaddition with epoxides. The chemical structure and bondings of PIL@NENPs was further investigated using XPS spectroscopy. The wide scan XPS (Fig. 3 (a)) survey spectrum showed that C, N and Br elements were simultaneously present in the PIL@NENPs. In particular, the Br anion as a nucleophile is clearly visible in the spectrum, which plays an important role in CO2 cycloaddition and was well retained in the PIL@NENPs composite. In the deconvoluted C 1s XPS spectra of PIL@NENPs (Fig. 3(b)), three distinct peaks were deconvoluted at 284.4 eV, 286.8 eV and 287.8 eV, which are assigned to the C-C/C=C, C-N, and C=N groups, respectively [54]. In the N 1s XPS spectra (Fig. 3(c)), the peaks at the binding energies of 398.1 eV, 399.3 eV, and 400.9 eV were attributed to the contribution of C=N, N-H groups, and N+ (imidazole cations) respectively [51,55]. In the XPS spectra of Br 3d (Fig. 3(d)), the deconvoluted peaks at the binding energy of 67.2 eV and 68.1 eV were attributed to the contribution of Br 3d3/2 and Br 3d5/2 levels respectively, indicating the presence of Br anions paired with the imidazolium cations [56]. The surface morphology of PIL-NH2HBr, NENPs, and PIL@NENPs were characterized by SEM and the micrographs are presented in Fig. 4 . (a–c). It can be clearly seen that PIL-NH2HBr, NENPs, and PIL@NENPs were composed of irregular shaped particles with size in nanoscale. The particles of PIL-NH2HBr and NENPs were observed to smaller and loosely packed compared to the PIL@NENPs, where the particles are larger and fused each other to form a tightly packed sponge like appearance. It might be due to the fact that the further growth of particles could promoted by the loading NENPs on the surface of PIL-NH2HBr. Additionally, due to the surface linking effect of NENPs, the particles of PIL-NH2HBr were packed more closely in the hybrid material. The elemental mapping of PIL@NENPs showed that C, N, and Br elements were uniformly distributed in the composite, indicating that the active sites of PIL@NENPs are well integrated. The characterization results of SEM further intuitively proved that the PIL-NH2HBr and NENPs were successfully integrated to synthesize the PIL@NENPs composite material. 3.2 Evaluation of the catalytic performance After a detailed study on the chemical structure, textural and morphological properties of PIL-NH2HBr, NENPs, and PIL@NENPs, their catalytic performance for CO2 cycloaddition with epoxides was further investigated. The simplest epoxide Epichlorohydrin (ECH) was used as a model epoxide, and the catalytic performance of the catalyst was evaluated from the yield and selectivity of product, chloropropene carbonate (CPC). The cycloaddition of CO2 was not observed in the absence of catalyst. (Table 2 , (entry 1)). The catalytic activity of PIL-NH2HBr+NENPs is higher than that of PIL-NH2HBr or NENPs alone (Table 2, (entries 2-3, 5)). This is because PIL-NH2HBr and NENPs have different active sites, and the mixture still has a synergistic catalytic effect. However, the catalytic activity of PIL-NH2HBr+NENPs is lower than that of PIL@NENPs (Table 2, (entry 4)). This may be due to the fact that in PIL@NENPs, the in-situ compounding of PIL-NH2HBr and NENPs makes the binding between different active sites closer, which is more conducive to exerting a synergistic catalytic effect. In general, the multi-active site integration strategy of in situ composite is successful in CO2 cycloaddition. To further explore and evaluate the catalytic activities of PIL-NH2HBr, NENPs, and PIL@NENPs, the influence of reaction temperature on their catalytic activity was investigated. Fig. 5 showed that the yield of CPC was increased significantly with the increase of reaction temperature for all of the catalysts, while the selectivity remained same in high level. As can be seen from Fig. 5(a), as the reaction temperature increases from 90℃ to 110℃, the yield of CPC increases rapidly from 52 % to 91 %. When the temperature increased to 120℃, the yield of CPC increased only slightly to 98 % due to the consumption of ECH substrate. When the temperature continued to increase to 140℃, the yield of CPC remained basically unchanged due to the almost complete reaction of the ECH substrate. Considering energy consumption and reaction efficiency comprehensively, it is more reasonable to choose 110℃ as the optimal reaction temperature. Similarly, the optimal reaction temperature of NENPs is 120℃ (Fig. 5(b)), and the optimal reaction temperature of PIL-NH2HBr is 140℃ (Fig. 5(c)). In addition, in order to better reflect the activity differences of the three catalysts PIL-NH2HBr, NENPs and PIL@NENPs, the effects of temperature on the catalytic activity were compared together (Fig. S1). It is obvious that the catalytic activity of PIL@NENPs is higher than that of NENPs and PIL-NH2HBr. For the PIL@NENPs composite, only low reaction temperature was required for providing a comparable catalytic efficiency, which is very attractive in terms of reducing the energy consumption and cost and improving the production efficiency. Therefore, in order to evaluate the catalytic performance of PIL@NENPs very efficiently, the effects of reaction time and CO2 pressure on CPC selectivity and yield were further investigated. The effect of initial CO2 pressure on the yield of CPC is shown in Fig. 6 (a). The initial pressure of CO2 has little effect on the cycloaddition reaction of CO2 and epoxide. As the initial pressure of CO2 increases from 0.25 MPa to 2 MPa, the yield of CPC slowly increases from 76 % to 99 %, and the selectivity of CPC remained more or less same to 99 %. Considering that when the initial pressure of CO2 is 1MPa, CPC has reached a relatively satisfactory yield of 91 %. And continuing to increase the CO2 initial pressure has little effect on the CPC yield, so 1MPa is selected as the optimal CO2 initial pressure. The effect of reaction time on the yield of cyclic carbonate is shown in Fig. 6(b). As the reaction time prolongs, the reactant ECH is gradually converted, so the yield of CPC gradually increases. Within the reaction time of 2-10 h, the yield of CPC gradually increased from 29 % to 98 % as the reaction time increased. The above results indicate that prolonging the reaction period, increasing the initial CO2 pressure and increasing the reaction temperature could promote the efficiency of the catalyst for CO2 cycloaddition with ECH. However, considering the factors such as energy, efficiency and process cost, it is determined that the optimal conditions to catalyze the CO2 cycloaddition with ECH over PIL@NENPs hybrid is as follows: 110℃ and 1 MPa CO2 pressure for a period of 8 h. To highlight the advantages of PIL@NENPs composite catalyst, a comparison was made with previously reported catalysts (Table 3 ). Some early reported catalysts often needed the use of solvents during the reaction to obtain better catalytic activity, which not only increases the production costs, but also causes the environmental pollution (Table 3 (entry 1)). Moreover, many catalysts required the use of co-catalysts, such as tetrabutylammonium bromide (TBAB), to achieve high catalytic performance, which undoubtedly increases the cost of purification process and further reasons for environmental pollution (Table 3 (entries 2-3)). In the absence of co-catalysts and solvents, high reaction temperatures (≥150℃) are essential for the CO2 cycloaddition, which unquestionably demands high energy consumption (Table 3 (entries 4-5)). Similar to this article, the use of ionic liquids to modify catalysts can not only introduce nucleophiles but also avoid contamination of cocatalysts, which is an effective method to improve the activity of catalysts. However, higher temperatures (≥120℃) are still required due to the limited number of nucleophiles modified on the catalyst (Table 3 (entries 6-8)). There are some research reports, where the reaction temperature was reduced by prolonging the reaction time, which is very unfavorable for the production efficiency (Table 3 (entries 9-10)). In contrast, the newly reported PIL@NENPs composite catalyst in this work has highly modest advantages in terms of low reaction temperature, reasonable reaction time, and absolutely free from any co-catalysts and solvents (Table 3 (entry 11)). Thus, the PIL@NENPs composite is a worthy heterogeneous catalyst for the CO2 cycloaddition reaction that can solve the limitations associated with the ordinary catalysts. 3.3 Catalyst versatility and recyclability Through the comparison with previously reported catalysts, the catalytic activity of PIL@NENPs was well demonstrated. This session could highlight the recyclability and versatility of PIL@NENPs. As shown, the PIL@NENPs sample have efficient catalytic activity for a set of epoxides with different substituent groups (Table 4 ). The reason for the difference in the catalytic activity might be related to the presence of electron withdrawing/donating groups and the steric effect of substituent in the epoxide. The ring-opening of epoxides is favored due to effect of electron-withdrawing groups and low steric hindrance. Therefore, epoxides with electron-withdrawing groups (Table 4, (entry 1)) and less steric hindrance (Table 4, (entries 2-3)) results better catalytic activity. The epoxides with high steric hindrance in their structure (Table 4, (entries 4-5)) was found to be yielding low product. when the epoxide has both electron-withdrawing groups and large steric hindrance, the reactivity further decreases (Table 4, (entries 6-7). Fortunately, the above epoxides can be efficiently converted into the corresponding cyclic carbonates by extending the reaction time. Cyclohexene oxide is one of the least reactive epoxides because structurally it is an internal epoxide and possesses high steric hindrance around the epoxide ring. Therefore, there was no conversion to the corresponding cyclic carbonate at all after 8 h of reaction (Table 4, (entry 8). The recyclability of a heterogeneous catalyst is of great importance when it comes in the industrial application level, and the reusability of the PIL@NENPs was further investigated. As can be seen from Fig. 7 (a), Although the catalytic activity of PIL@NENPs decreased slightly after each cycle, a satisfactory yield of 88 % could still be achieved after 6 cycles. To further explore the reason for the activity decrease, the recycled catalyst was characterized. As shown in Fig. 7(b), the FT-IR spectrum shows that the recycled PIL@NENPs retain all typical characteristic peaks (especially the triazine ring). And a new peak appears at 1800 cm-1, which is attributed to the stretching vibration of the C=O bond of CPC [66], indicating that a small amount of CPC remains in the catalyst. It further explains that the reason for the slight decrease in activity of PIL@NENPs after recycling may be that a small amount of product residues occupies part of the active sites. 3.4 DFT studies with plausible reaction mechanism The interaction of each active sites in PIL@NENPs with epoxides and CO2 was further investigated by DFT computation (Fig. 8 ). Due to the reproducibility of the PIL@NENPs structural unit, a typical structure including all functional groups was constructed and optimized. (Fig. S9). Firstly, the interaction between N sites on two triazine rings such as the triazine rings of melamine or cyanuric chloride, and CO2 were calculated respectively. The calculations showed that after the interaction of CO2 with the N atoms on the triazine ring of melamine or cyanuric chloride, the linear bond angle was changed from 180.00° to 176.48° and 177.03°, respectively. The results confirmed that different triazine rings in the catalyst structure had a strong activation effect on CO2, and the activated and bent CO2 molecules were more conducive to the subsequent transformation. The interaction of -NH- groups with ECH were further calculated and the results had shown that when ECH forms hydrogen bonds with -NH- groups of NENPs, the lengths of C-O bonds in ECH was increased from 1.435 Å to 1.440 Å and 1.433 Å to 1.436 Å, respectively. However, when the ECH forms hydrogen bonds with the -NH- groups at the covalent linkages of PIL@NENPs, the lengths of C-O bonds in ECH were found to be increased from 1.435 Å to 1.443 Å and 1.433 Å to 1.446 Å, respectively. Obviously, after the hydrogen bond formation of ECH with -NH- groups, the C-O bond length of ECH becomes longer, which results in the ring opening process easier to occur. Next, the nucleophilic attack of nucleophile (Br anion) on ECH in PIL@NENPs was studied. The DFT calculations validated that that when ECH interacts with the Br anion, the lengths of C-O bonds in ECH were increased from 1.435 Å to 1.440 Å and 1.433 Å to 1.429 Å, respectively. The nucleophilic attack of Br anion made the β-C-O bond of ECH to become longer and the α-C-O bond to shorter, indicating that ECH is easier to open from the β-C-O bond. Due to the synergistic effect of multiple active sites in PIL@NENPs with different functions, the cycloaddition of CO2 with epoxides can be effectively catalyzed by PIL@NENPs under relatively mild conditions. By combining the catalytic activity, DFT computation and previous literature [29,67,68], a possible reaction mechanism for the cycloaddition of CO2 with epoxide catalyzed by PIL@NENPs was proposed (Fig. 9 ). The catalytic reaction is expected to start by adsorbing and activating the epoxide and CO2 with PIL@NENPs. The -NH- groups of PIL@NENPs act as a hydrogen bond donor to form hydrogen bonds with the O atom of epoxide and activates the epoxide molecule. Meanwhile, the CO2 also gets activated by abundant N sites in PIL@NENPs. Secondly, the Br anions or N atoms containing lone pairs of electrons, act as nucleophilic reagents to attack the C atom of epoxide with small steric hindrance to promote the opening of epoxides and forms oxyanion intermediate. Thirdly, the activated CO2 gets inserted into the oxyanion intermediate to form the alkyl carbonate intermediate species. Finally, by an intramolecular ring-closing process, the nucleophile gets detached from the species and forms cyclic carbonate with the simultaneous regaining of the catalyst structure. 4 Conclusions A hybrid composite catalyst, PIL@NENPs was successfully prepared by an in-situ synthesis of NENPs through the condensation of cyanuric chloride and melamine on PIL-NH2HBr. The characterization techniques demonstrated the successful synthesis of PIL-NH2HBr, NENPs, and PIL@NENPs. The high CO2 adsorption capacity of NENPs was integrated into PIL@NENPs, which provides a favorable environment for the subsequent CO2 catalytic conversion. The catalytic performance of the catalysts for CO2 cycloaddition with epoxides had shown that the PIL@NENPs sample exhibited better catalytic activity than PIL-NH2HBr and NENPs, due to the synergistic effect of multiple active sites in PIL@NENPs. In addition, the PIL@NENPs showed good catalytic stability and recyclability as well as high efficiency towards various epoxides with different functional groups. The DFT calculations revealed the activation of epoxides by HBDs/Br anions and CO2 by N sites, respectively in the catalyst structure. Finally, a possible reaction mechanism for CO2 cycloaddition catalyzed by PIL@NENPs was proposed. Overall, a novel hybrid catalyst with multiple active sites was synthesized through a covalent integration strategy, which is expected to provide a reference for the design of efficient heterogeneous catalysts. coredata.dc:description: The conversion CO2 into highly value-added chemicals requires the development of efficient heterogenous catalysts in the cycloaddition reaction. Herein, the covalent integration strategy of amino-functionalized poly(ionic liquid)s (PIL-NH2HBr) with nitrogen-enriched nano-porous polytriazines (NENPs) was used to synthesize a novel hybrid catalyst, labelled as PIL@NENPs. Several characterization techniques were used to confirm the effective synthesis of PIL-NH2HBr, NENPs and PIL@NENPs composites. Through the PIL-NH2HBr surface integration, the CO2 adsorption capacity of NENPs was greatly improved in the PIL@NENPs composites. The catalytic activity studies shown that the PIL@NENPs exhibited better catalytic activity than PIL-NH2HBr and NENPs in CO2 cycloaddition reaction due to their synergetic effects. Moreover, the PIL@NENPs composite was found to be very easy to separate, had shown good stability and recyclability, and very effective for a variety of epoxides in the CO2 cycloaddition reaction. The Density Functional Theory (DFT) calculations further revealed that the epoxides were activated by hydrogen bond donor (HBD) groups and Br anions whereas the CO2 was activated by N sites. Finally, combining the DFT calculations and activities of different catalysts, a possible reaction mechanism for CO2 cycloaddition catalyzed by PIL@NENPs was proposed.
coredata.dc:title: PIL@NENPs composite as a synergetic heterogeneous catalyst to enhance the efficiency of CO2 cycloaddition with epoxides
